utterances: Survivor even is now coming up as a response - in the context in the name of diversity - coming up with racial matching and putting tribes of blacks and Asians and whites and Hispanic - what kind of nonsense is this?
As if the only way to increase diversity on television is to have separatism and segregation.
What's next?
Blacks who marry white against blacks who marry their own kind?
This is just silliness, it's craziness.
Well, you know what…
That might be a good TV show, Mike.
We have got to respond to it and say no.
Well, I tell you what, Mike.
It sounds like maybe we'll have to revisit this.
Maybe after a month, when half these shows have been cancelled, we'll see who survives.
Precisely.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Let's move on.
We're now officially into the fall campaign season.
It's something that we are not likely to see a lot of on television - it appears, as the campaigns heat up - are pictures of President George W.
Bush with every Republican candidate trying to hold onto his or her Congressional seat.
It seems Republican candidates are beginning to distance themselves from the president in very public ways.
I'm thinking now just of Maryland yesterday.
How risky, Roland Martin, is that strategy for the candidates?

First of all, it's not risky at all because it's no different when President Clinton was in office, when candidates wanted him to raise money but they did not want this face seen anywhere near voters.
And so it happens.
The White House understands that.
And so frankly, they're going to go along with it.
They're going to remain sort of in a stealth role, continue to raise funds.
And so, what you also find, though, that if there is a major turnaround in this war on terror, if something happens, then the president's number is probably going to go up 10, 12 points.
Then you're going to see candidates flocking to stand right next to him.
This is the nature of politics.
What do you say, Laura?
And when the 32,000 LED lights inside blared on, it was dazzling.
Even in the middle of the afternoon, it hurt to look right at it.
Proposition 8, yes.
Well, I - Roland mentioned raising funds.
I think this is going to be the crucial demonstration of the Republican Party's power.
Even Rahm Emanuel has been saying that he's really worried about the money.
Rahm Emanuel, of course, being the lead political drive behind the Democratic Party's effort to take back the House.
The money's going to have to be parsed and it's going to have to be targeted in certain races.
For example, it's clear that the Republican Party's going to have to focus on Congress.
It's going to have to, you know, fall away from many of these gubernatorial races.
For example, the one here in Illinois.
Judy Baar Topinka is running against Robert Goya, but Judy Baar Topinka is the Republican candidate.
She was hoping - she, in fact, agreed to, I think stupidly agreed to campaign with Bush and agreed to appear with him in an exchange for a promise of money.
Well, that money's probably not going to be as forthcoming as she thought because they're really going to have to focus.

But you also will see Bush's picture appear in campaign ads, except they will be the Democratic Party's campaign ads and they will be showing pictures of Bush in the past with these Republican candidates.
They're going to ram that down their throats.
Let me put a different question to you, Michael Meyers.
There are 60-plus days or so left before the election, and pundits have all but given the House over to the Democrats.
With the Senate, most saying a little too close to call at the moment.
But predictions, of course, are just that - predictions.
So how realistic do you see the prospects of the Democrats retaking both houses for the first time since 1994?
I don't go with the pundits and I don't go with polls, as Walter Mondale said to his chagrin.
Polls don't vote, people vote.
People vote, polls don't vote.
I think people are not - Bush is not on the ballot except to people who want to put him on the ballot thinking that he's vulnerable.
But people are not going into the voting booth looking for George Bush's name.
George Bush knows and his handlers know that this election - and all the elections in this off year - are local.
And therefore, the local candidates are running the best they can based on what they believe - their own electorate believes.
And they will pander to what their electorate believes.
But nationally, they're preparing for the big deal.
And that is, Bush's handlers are saying, we are still in a culture war.
Bush represents the people who are against abortion.
He represents people who are against gay marriage.
He represents people who are against stem cell research.

And everything, in terms of the culture - where people are concerned that the, quote-unquote, liberals or the Democrats are destroying the American culture -that's what they're hoping people will vote for.
But, Michael…
Michael, Michael, I…
…let's play it out.
Michael…
But one other thing, they're also saying that Bush represents the best thing we have against terrorism.
I think that you're…
And they're stoking that.
So, you know, the alternative is the Democrats.
And I think the Democrats get scared talking about culture issues and they get scared talking about terrorism.
Yeah, but I think you have some disagreement.
Go ahead.
Michael, I think you said that they're hoping that the cultural issues will be front and center, but they're not going to be.
It's going to be Iraq.
It's going to be terrorism.
It's going to be national security, and I think the Democrats can make…
And the economy.
…and the economy, absolutely.
As people continue to look, show up at those gas stations with those high prices.
There's so much discomfort…
Gas prices are going down right before the election…
They're up and down, they're up and down.
Just wait till tomorrow.
But I think the economy is going to be a really important key issue.
The culture stuff is going by the wayside.
And look, President Bush's handlers understood this in January when they kept saying we have to make the war on terror the principal position of this midterm election.
They understand that.
They know that when it comes to domestic issues, the president is woefully weak.
So Social Security, immigration.
They're backing away from immigration right now.
Every major domestic issue they're backing away from.
They're hoping and praying it's a matter of terror, that something indeed does happen.
Oh come on, Roland.
You think they're hoping for a terrorist attack?
No, I said, no, no…
That's not what he said…
Easy.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Look at what happens in terms of…
They're predicting one.
They're not hoping for one.
When we had red alert, orange alert and then pink alert, whatever we have.
We don't have those alerts anymore.
But let me bring this in…
Let me, let me bring in the issue.
Let me bring in the issue.
Let me bring this in, because I want to make sure that we get an opportunity to hit it before our time runs out, because Roland raised the issue of terrorism, and all of you have touched on it.
And I think that you're quite right.

But, with the latest quarterly Pentagon report reporting a grim picture of the rise in casualties in Iraq - which is sort of the face of terrorism at the moment - the White House has taken a different tack in its defense of the war from saying that we must and we will win the war to now saying we must not lose.
